Dear RICHARD WATKINS:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
02/13/2025. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action
plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and
must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager, Rorie Dodge-Pifer at (517) 899-6024.
Sincerely,
Mark Hunter, Licensing Consultant

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
CPA Rule 400.12422 Foster care case record
• (3) The record must contain all the following
information:
• (e) Change of placement documentation as
required by R 400.12405.
One of the two closed foster care records reviewed did not include a copy of the
discharge documentation (DHHS-69) that is required for compliance with this rule.
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans
• (2) An agency shall complete written service plans
for each child and parent or parents, as follows:
• (b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial
removal and at least once every 90
calendar days thereafter.
One of the six current foster child records reviewed contained an Updated Service
Plan for the time period 12/13/2023 to 03/11/2024 that was completed 03/25/2024.
Repeat Violation Established
2023 Renewal Evaluation, CAP Approved 11/21/2023.
2

CPA Rule 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy
• (1) An agency's medical and dental care policy
must, include all the following:
• (c) A physical examination for each child as
follows, unless a greater frequency is
medically indicated:
• (ii) A physical examination every 14
months.
One of the six current foster child records reviewed did not include documentation
the foster child had received/completed an updated physical examination within the
time period required by this rule. The most recent physical examination
documented was completed 04/28/2023. An updated physical was due to be
completed by 06/28/2024.
CPA Rule 400.12605 Adoptive family evaluation
• (3) The report must assess all the following:
• (k) The age, number, gender, race, ethnic
background, and characteristics of children
preferred by the applicants.
Three of the three Adoptive Family Evaluations/Assessments reviewed did not
include the age, number, gender, race, ethnic background, and characteristics of
children preferred by the applicants and recommended/approved by the agency.
Each of the three assessments were completed for specific identified children, but
did not indicate/identify the characteristics of the children as required by this rule.

VI. EVALUATION OF PERIOD UNDER REVIEW
Maltreatment in Care
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during the licensing
period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 4 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows:
The agency submitted a corrective action plan for the renewal evaluation
completed 11/03/2023. Areas identified in noncompliance as a part of that
evaluation were Rules 327 (7)(4), 418 (2)(b) (5) and (6). This CAP was approved
by DCWL 11/21/2023. Action steps for 327(7) included a review of social work
contacts, 327(4) included reminders to proofread foster home special investigation
reports for verbal summaries, 418(2)(b) included weekly KPI review meetings,
418(5) included additional social work contacts and monitoring for report
signatures, and 418(6) included reminders during Team Meetings. The only area
identified as a repeat noncompliance as a part of this interim evaluation was
418(2)(b).
The agency submitted a CAP for 2024SIC00001067. Noncompliance was
identified for Rule 421(4) as a part of this investigation. The CAP for this
noncompliance was approved by DCWL 4/10/2024, completed 06/13/2024, and
verified 07/10/2024. Reviewed weekly and monthly emails and Team Meeting
minutes that documented KPI were reviewed for verification.
The agency submitted a CAP for 2024SIC00001714. Noncompliance with Rule
325(1) was identified as a part of this special investigation. The CAP for this
noncompliance was approved by DCWL 10/11/2024 and final completion is due
04/11/2025 and is currently being monitored. Action steps include a review of
applicants file history and additional supervisory reviews and meetings with
certification staff.
The agency submitted a CAP for 2024SIC00001781. Noncompliance with Rule
206(2) was identified as a part of this special investigation. The CAP was
approved by DCWL 10/31/2024 and final completion is due 04/30/2025. Action
steps included increased communication with the court, child attorneys, and other
related investigative bodies. This continues to be monitored.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator Assessment provided a review of the corrective action
plans and action steps submitted by the agency associated with the renewal
evaluation completed 11/03/2023. Progress in the areas to achieve compliance
4

as well as challenges were also identified. One continuing challenge is the
agency's ability to recruit and maintain appropriate staff to manage/provide
appropriate services.
Financial Overview
There are no financial concerns identified based on the review of the facility's
budget and the agency's financial audit.
Staff Interviews
Child Welfare Staff participated in entrance and exit conferences. Staff interviews
did not identify any concerns except for the continuing challenge to recruit and
maintain/retain staff.
Description of Agency Walk Through
The agency maintains sufficient office space, equipment and supplies to ensure
delivery of foster care, licensing and adoption services. All files were stored
securely and there is a cross shredder for CHRI.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
The analyst identified four safety alerts.
Safety Alert #1: One relative home required a safety plan associated with the water
hazard (duck pond) behind the home.
Resolution: A safety plan was developed and was approved by DCWL on 6/26/2024.
Safety Alert #2: One licensed foster home needed a door alarm as they had a water
hazard outside.
Resolution: A door alarm was installed and confirmation included pictures and an
onsite visit. Resolution was approved by DCWL on 06/26/2024.
Safety Alert #3: One licensed foster home required another smoke detector.
Resolution: The smoke detector was installed and confirmation/compliance included
picture documentation. Compliance was approved by DCWL on 6/26/2024.
Safety Alert #4: One relative home needed a smoke detector.
Resolution: The smoke detector was installed and compliance confirmation included
pictures. Resolution was approved by DCWL on 08/05/2024.
5

VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
